content:
Please add to the constraints that you can assume that the tree shadows are not over-lapping.

This is CRITICAL to the solution and isn't currently mentioned. I just did this clash and was so confused at first how I'm meant to solve this.

The zenith part is irrelevant and confusing. We are given the radius of each tree's shadow. You should make that clear. At zenith the shadow will be the same as the area of the tree only at the correct latitude for that time of year, so the zenith part is not really that helpful and it makes the problem seem a LOT harder than it is.

Not very fair to clashers who speak English as a second language, I found this hard to read as a native speaker. Three people quit with 0% in my clash after 3 minutes.

I am sorry but, contrary to what some have stated, the statement is not clear at all.
First, it is assumed that all the trees cast a shadow only on the lawn (that is, there is no tree close enough to the border such that part of its shadow is cast outside the lawn). I see no such guarantee in the statement.
Secondly, it is also assumed that the angle between the sun rays and the local horizon at solar noon is exactly 90° (i.e the solar zenith angle is 0°).
That is only true between the tropics of Cancer and Capricorn, and only twice a year at very specific dates depending on the latitude. (Google Lahaina Noon)
In any other part of the world, or at any other date, this simply does not hold true.
Please have a look at this graph: 
https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6a/Solar_Zenith_Angle_min.png
As you can see the zenith angle can be very large depending on your latitude and the time of the year, causing great variations in the expected output.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Description is clear. Clash is a bit easy, but challengy for code length clashes imho

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I love the idea, and the translation seems perfect. Python solution (Slightly golfed):
import math
I=input
w,l=map(int,I().split()) 
a=w*l
n=int(I())
t=sum([math.pi*float(I())**2 for i in[1]*n])
I([round(a-t,2),0][t>a])
I think zenit is supposed to have an h at the end, zenith.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I understood it pretty quickly, I didn't find it hard but I found it clear and well explained.

I didn't want to modify your contribution but here are a few changes

SAMPLE STATEMENT:
{{Sorry for translation : please, feel free to improve with better english words ;-)}}
Max has a [[W]] width and [[L]] length lawn on which he has planted [[N]] bushy trees of radius [[r]], you must output the unshaded area [[S]] when the sun is at its zenith ( directly overhead ).

SAMPLE INPUT:
<<Line 1:>> [[W]], [[L]] integers separated by space
<<Line 2:>> [[n]]
<<Next [[n]] Lines:>> float [[r]]

SAMPLE STUB GENERATOR INPUT:
read W:int L:int
read N:int
loop n read r:float

Yes, thanks @The_ZimaBlue !
I know you're already submitted some contributions, and your experience i just what i need ;-) ...

Effectively, in my first original input descriptions, test cases and Solution : W and L were in the same line ... I agree with you : it's better :-).

But when generating stub : problem ... no matter how to generate correct reading for 2 int from same line ... so disappointed :-( ! ... => manual split all into 2 separated input lines :-( !

=> Thanks to you : Updated back all my texts in accordance to this new (for me) best functionality !

OK, thanks @Necromonkey for your reply and orthographic recommendation ;-) !
-> I'ts corrected :-) ...

Thanks XorZy for your feedback.
As you mentioned, the statements are really simplified for this CoC.
> In this one (future one may be different), i specially checked that none of the trees are too close to the border to avoid transforming this CoC to mathematical problem more than programing CoC. I agree with you : maybe more fun but complex a bit more++ the coding ;-) ...
> Yes, the sun rays are not same angle everywhere beyond the earth; they are not really parallel if you would consider scientific approach. I choose to simplify again to meet 15minuts only coding solvable ;-) !
=> Do you think these specifications are awkwardly missing to the constraints or statements ?

Hi StepBack13 : I'm sorry for your disappointment ...

  Well, according to your profile, you've already participate to many (more than 500) others clahs and observed, as me, that regularly some abandon because of "too hard for them" or no patience to try to understand ... i can't do anything for their choice ...

  Compared to the one i get a few days ago (old music partition), I think this one not a hard one, but i can imagine that it may seem to be a bit difficult for some (beginning ?) clashers ...
-> You're not, and I'd like to congratulate you for your report.
=> If possible (?), i'm interested by the clash report link.

So, as you can consider in the new Constraints part, i've integrated your feedback ... i hope clearly enough for next clashers ?

Unfortunately, English is not my native language, so google helps me, but some translations are ... (bip)
-> if you think about a better title word : please suggest me ... would you ?

Thank you for your reply. 
I hope my comment did not sound too harsh.
The fact that the people who approved this problem did not take the time to study it properly did annoy me a little, I admit.
It might be nit-picking be I like statements that are as unambiguous as possible.
My problem is not with the difficulty of the clash, I don't think it needs to be harder, it is fine as it is.
You only need to specify that the sun is considered to be directly above at solar noon and that no shadow is cast outside the lawn.
This way there is no possible ambiguity.

Hi XorZy : i've integrated your suggestions in the Constraints part :-) !
-> Happy to clarify if it could be more useful during the Coc ...

Isn't why this section is called "Community contributions" ;-) ?
Hi The_ZimaBlue : do you think this CoC is now ready for Approval, please ?
